[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: EncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Digest validation] Does verify_decryption_key() validate that the digest parameter is well-formed and not maliciously crafted, or can an attacker pass invalid digests to cause panics, incorrect verification results, or side-channel leaks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: AugmentedEncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Digest binding] Is the digest properly cryptographically bound to the decryption key being verified, or can an attacker mix-and-match digests and decryption keys from different epochs or batches? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: EncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Digest collision] If two different ID sets hash to the same digest due to collision or malicious construction, can an attacker use a decryption key for one set to decrypt the other, breaking BIBE isolation guarantees? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: AugmentedEncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Digest malleability] Can an attacker manipulate the digest parameter in non-semantic ways (e.g., changing internal round number) while maintaining verification validity, enabling replay or cross-batch attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: EncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Decryption key validation] Does verify_decryption_key() validate that the decryption_key parameter contains valid G1Affine signature points, or can an attacker pass invalid points to cause verification bypass or panic? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: AugmentedEncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Key reconstruction attack] If decryption_key is supposed to be reconstructed from threshold shares, does verification check that reconstruction was done correctly, or can an attacker supply a non-reconstructed key that passes verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: EncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Key type confusion] Can an attacker pass a decryption key intended for a different encryption key instance, and does verification properly reject cross-key usage that would break security? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: AugmentedEncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Decryption key reuse] Can the same decryption_key be verified against multiple different digests or encryption keys, and does this enable any attack where a key obtained for one purpose is reused maliciously elsewhere? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: EncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Pairing precomputation] Is the pairing computation in BIBEMasterPublicKey verification optimized with precomputation, or does each verification call perform expensive pairing operations that enable DoS through verification flooding? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: AugmentedEncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Pairing malleability] Can an attacker exploit bilinear pairing properties to create alternative decryption keys that satisfy the verification equation but decrypt to different plaintexts? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: EncryptionKey::verify_decryption_key()] [Multi-pairing efficiency] If multiple verifications are needed, does the implementation batch verify using multi-pairing, or does sequential verification enable timing attacks to distinguish valid from invalid keys? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Struct: EncryptionKey] [G1/G2 confusion] Are all pairing operations correctly using G1 for signatures and G2 for public keys (or vice versa), or can swapping groups enable attacks that break the Type-III pairing security assumption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Fields: pub(crate)] [Module visibility exploit] Since sig_mpk_g2, tau_g2, and tau_mpk_g2 are pub(crate), can code in the same crate directly mutate these fields without going through the constructor, creating invalid key states? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Struct: EncryptionKey] [Field mutation] Are the struct fields actually immutable once constructed, or can safe Rust code obtain mutable references and modify G2Affine values, breaking key integrity? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Struct: AugmentedEncryptionKey] [Internal mutability] Do G2Affine types use interior mutability (e.g., Cell, RefCell), enabling mutation even through shared references, which could allow concurrent modification attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Methods: new()] [Public constructor] Should the new() constructors be pub(crate) instead of pub to prevent external crates from creating potentially invalid keys without proper setup validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Derive: Serialize, Deserialize] [Deserialization of untrusted data] When deserializing EncryptionKey from network messages or storage, can an attacker craft malicious payloads that exploit vulnerabilities in ark_de to achieve RCE or DoS? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Derive: Serialize, Deserialize] [Serialization format stability] Is the serialization format stable across versions, or can serialized keys from older versions deserialize to different values in newer code, causing consensus divergence? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Serialize: ark_se] [Serialization errors] Can serialization fail for valid EncryptionKey instances due to edge cases in ark_se, and are these errors properly handled or can they cause validator panics? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Deserialize: ark_de] [Version downgrade attack] Can an attacker replay serialized keys from older protocol versions to newer validators, exploiting differences in validation or cryptographic assumptions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Derive: Serialize, Deserialize] [Size limit enforcement] Does deserialization enforce maximum size limits on serialized data, or can an attacker send extremely large payloads to cause memory exhaustion during deserialization? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Struct: EncryptionKey] [Key uniqueness] Are EncryptionKey instances globally unique per setup/epoch, or can key reuse across different contexts enable cross-context attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Struct: AugmentedEncryptionKey] [Augmentation semantics] What additional security properties does AugmentedEncryptionKey provide over EncryptionKey, and can an attacker exploit scenarios where regular keys are used instead of augmented ones? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Function: verify_decryption_key()] [Revocation support] Is there any mechanism to revoke or invalidate encryption keys, or can compromised keys remain valid indefinitely, enabling long-term attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-batch-encryption/src/shared/encryption_key.rs] [Struct: EncryptionKey] [Key rotation] Does the protocol support key rotation, and can an attacker exploit the transition period between old and new keys to perform attacks? (Medium)
